Intervention Type/Peacebuilding:
Among my roles are: conflict resolution in the community, identifying vulnerable households and have them priotritized in humanitarian aids
Involve in decision making concerning the community
Advocating for community self reliance through farming " I even have a farm as a demonstration to the rest of the community members that it's important to make your own food and not rely on humanitarian assistance."
Advocating for peaceful co-existence amongst the community members.
Programming Gaps/Peacebuilding:
Education and health services are lacking in the payams like Nyandit and Dengjock "when someone is severely sick, they have to be carried up to Akobo Hospital, a distance of about 2-3 hours."
"Peace building efforts should be scaled up."

Intervention Type/Peacebuilding: "Over the past few years, there was rampant revenge killing throughout the county but it has subsided since the turn of this year thanks to peace dialogues spearheaded by conflict management and peace making NGOs and religious leaders." There are sports matches organized across the county and they bring youth from rival/reveng killing-affected communities together.

Shocks/Flood: Dry spelt and then too much rain that destroyed crops and disrupted farming activities

Programming Gaps/Agriculture:
There are NGOs implementing WASH but there is insufficiency of boreholes in the payams such as Nyandit, Dengjok and Gakdong.
There are some items that are distributed without prior assessment of the community preferrences; these include distribution of farming tools which are not being used resulting to a waste of resources.
Stresses/Conflict:
"Dry spelt from April to June followed by excessive rain
Murle attacks
Revenge killing"

Intervention Type/Nutrition:
Supplying commodities to the market; identify demand gaps and avail the demanded items
Give food on credit during times of food scarcity and wait until they are able to pay back
Shocks/Financial:
In the last 12 months, hunger has been very severe as crops were destroyed by too much rain and food assistance delayed.
Prices of commodities have gone up from the supply source which is Ethiopia and consequently have risen here as well

Stresses/Conflict:
Too much rain that destroyed crops which resulted in hunger 
Lack of roads led to scarcity of commodities 
Revenge killing

Intervention Type/Agriculture:
Involve in conflict resolution initiatives on revenge killings
Advocate for self reliance through agriculture (this awareness is carried out through Youth Sub-offices in the payams)
We have formed farming and fishing groups to showcase livelihood disversification.
Programming Gaps/Education:
Agricultural tools
Primary education in the payams is lacking
Primary health care in the payams is also on and off

Stresses/Conflict:
Hunger caused by too much rain and delay of food aid as people depend on food aid
Murle attacks (abduction, killing and cattle raiding)
Revenge killing
High prices caused by lack of roads

Intervention Type/Agriculture: Humanitarian assistance by NGOs,  sell of animals, early planting of crops and diversifiaction of diet; alternative source of livelihoods;
Programming Gaps/Education: poor road networks; poor telecommunication networks across the county except chukudum town; inadquate health care centers; poor education system due to unqualified teachers.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: alternative source of livelihoods such as VSLA activities, petty trade and early planting of crops is more useful

Shocks/Pests: prolong dry spell that occurred between May-Oct 2022 leads to poor harvest, low market linkages, food insecurity in some HHs animal diseases which started since 2019 up to date, limited vetinary services;  water scarcity in places like kimantong, Nauro,lotukei etc; women are mostly affected due to high price increases, their main livelihoods farming was affceted as a result of long dry spell and pest & diseases.

Intervention Type/Protection: He is the deputy youth leader for Budi county, the support the community  by participating in peace dialoque organize by Ips ( CDSS,ROG, CRS); sensitize the youth in different payams on the danger of conflicts, GBVs, rubbery, road ambush,  too much alcohol consumption & advocate for youth participation in farming as well as use of local seeds that resist drought.
Programming Gaps/WASH: limited life skills activities across the county, poor hygiene & sanitation , lack of referal pathway for GBV survisors, insecurity, inadquate sources of safe drinking water, lack of mechanised equipments like tractors

Programming Gaps/Agriculture: inaccessibility to other Payams and big towns due to bad roads, Poor education system & lack of government scholarship, animal diseases and limited vetinery services, lack of Haffir for animals during dry season, lack of vocational training center for the youth & women
Intervention Type/Protection: Approaches use includes: peace dialoque with neighboring community facilitated by Ips; community sensitization on the dangers of GBVs; alcohol, road rubbery etc to youths, danger of bush burning, sensitizing youth on good management skills of their resoruces arcoss the county, training of youth on livelihoods skills and establishment of small business to support livelihoods.

Stresses/Conflict: Main shocks & stressor includes pest & diseases ( fall army worm occurred in April-May 2022), prolong dry spell, high rate of alcohol consumptions, insecurity due to cattle raiding, road ambush, rubbery etc; high rate of GBVs cases across the county results into killing, sucide, girl child compensation in case a person is killed during a fight, women are mostly affected by the shocks & stressor compare to men as they take all the family burden.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: Trainings & senisitaization of the community on the danger of GBVs, trauma healing activities by Ips like ROG,  training on the best agronomic practices

Programming Gaps/WASH: There is gap in education system, inadqaute safe drinking water sources across the county, poor roadnets affects movement mostly during rain seasons and leads to increase of food prices in market

lack of mechanized agricultural equipments, inadqaute health care centers mostly in the uplands, and poor road conditions leads to high maternal moterlity rate, poor telecommunication network except chukumdum town.

Stresses/Conflict: Pest & diseases ( fall army worm affects harvest in April-May), insecurity, high rate of GBVs cases at HHs level, many community members are truamatize due to the loss of their ones, separtion from their children due to the war etc.  How it affects: it create fears among the community and limit access to farms that are far from home areas, led to loss of lives, women are mostly affecetd because they carry great burden of families.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: A bit of improvement  in agricultural sector due to trainings on best agronomic practices, distribution of small ruminants animals like goats to widows & people with disability has improve livelihoods.

Programming Gaps/Agriculture: lack of mechanized agricultural equipments, inadqaute health care centers mostly in the uplands, and poor road conditions leads to high maternal moterlity rate, poor telecommunication network except chukumdum town.

Programming Gaps/Infastructure: There is gap in education system, inadqaute safe drinking water sources across the county, poor roadnets affects movement mostly during rain seasons and leads to increase of food prices in market

Intervention Type/Infrastructure: Iam a  business man and deals with supply of constructions materials; we do support the community with building materials that we bring from Uganda; we supply agricultural inputs such as tools, seeds,ox-plough etc
Stresses/Security Issues: Insecurity incidents in Kikilai  to Uganda road that occurred in May 2022 affects movement & businessmen; long dry spell from  Aug-Dec 2022; bad road networks limits access to other payams & big towns especially during rain season, high transport cost- leads to high market prices,  the effect of shocks & stressor in the county is,  there is increase in the prices of local produces, increase in GBVs cases at HHs due the demand for money women got from cash for work activities. women are mostly affected as they carry the family burden, men resorted to drinking alcohol as it's more cheeper than buying food from the market,

Intervention Type/Protection: No approaches develop to address increase in the market price; awareness activities on GBVs by some Ips like CRS, CDSS & ROG,

Programming Gaps/WASH: No much support from the government, most villages didn't received trainings on agro-best practices; poor education system due to unqualified teachers; lack of structures in some locations; insecurity; Poor hygiene and sanitaion open defeacation in most villages, inadqaute safe water sources in some villages where they depends on water from the streams

Shocks/Drought: Pest & diseases such as the fall army worm that happened in April-May 2022, Pronlong dry spell that occurred in August-Oct 2022, hunger experieneced by some HHs; c) women are greatly affected with the shocks & stressors since their main livelihoods activities such as farming was affected hence they have to labor more to get food for the HHs by collecting wild fruits, vegetables, firewood etc, Then men have to go far places looking for green pastures and water for their animals where they get involved in attacks by cattle raider from the neighboring communities.

Programming Gaps/Education:
•	Poor learning infrastructure, as most schools are operated under trees.
•	Lack of WASH facilities e.g., boreholes and pit latrines at schools
•	Lack of school equipment e.g., benches to learners and other learning 
•	Lack of motivation for teachers which affects learning.
•	Limited teacher accommodation facilities.

Stresses/Poverty:
•	Major shocks include: hunger and food insecurity as a result of rain-fed agriculture; economic shock characterized by high commodity prices nearly on daily basis especially in the last 12 months; gender base violence, prolonged dry spells (rain starts late – June and stops early – October yearly).

•	Hunger has contributed to dropouts of children out of school, and left vulnerable people resort to negative copping mechanism like robbery. Economic shocks have contributed to domestic gender base violence and deepened. 

•	Women are affected more as compared to men because they shoulder most of the family responsibility. Men are depressed due to failure to provide for the family. Girl child forced to drop out of school and forced to marry in order for the family to survive.

Programming Gaps/WASH:
The main challenges or gaps include:
•	Health: Currently, only Johanniter International and Cordaid are the ones providing health care in Jur River, and only few health facilities are supported. There’s need for more partners to strengthen the health sector so that children and pregnant women can access health care services in Jur River County.
•	In addition, during rainy season, and when flooding happens, there is high incidence of malaria among children and old people because there are no mosquito nets.
•	Water: There are few functional boreholes in Jur River county. 
•	Education: There are only few schools in Jur River with school structures. Majority of the schools are under trees and during rain season, learning is disrupted.

Shocks/Flood: Major shocks and stresses include: Floods that happens every year; prolonged dry spell which is always followed by floods between August and October each year, destroying crops, affects livestock and erodes existing livelihoods of the community, resulting in food insecurity and hunger. GBV, Health shocks as a result of floods increasing malaria incidence. Some of the stresses include: high commodity prices and poor essential service delivery.

Intervention Type/Economic:
1.	Floods: Digging of water passage channels around homes; relocating to higher grounds; relief aid.
2.	Prolonged dry spell: Provision of vegetable seeds, tools and training; small scale businesses e.g., bread baking, tailoring. 
3.	High commodity prices (economic shock): Economic empowerment of women and youths through training and provision of start-up kits; VSLA Training/kits; reducing expenditures in order to buy food; reducing the number of meals per day from 2 to 1.
4.	GBV (including forced marriages): Raising awareness among women and girls.
Programming Gaps/Protection:
1.	Education – not many women and girls have attended school for many reasons including poverty, negative cultural beliefs.
2.	NFIs for floods affected population.
3.	Poor health services 
4.	GBV prevention services

Intervention Type/Livelihoods:
1.	Economic empowerment of women and youths through training and provision of start-up kits and VSLA Training/kits support have been helpful in helping women become self-reliant.
2.	Vocational skills training in bread baking, tailoring – women are now able to earn from these businesses. 
3.	Provision of vegetable seeds, tools, and training – has provided alternative sources of food and income especially during prolonged dry spell.

Shocks/Drought: Main shocks include; Floods happen every year and always destroy houses, crops, and livestock; prolonged dry spell, every year; high commodity prices (economic shock) affects people on daily basis; GBV, mainly forced marriages as a result of the impact of other primary shocks.

Intervention Type/Agriculture:
1.	Cash/Food for asset – encouraged youths to work and enabled youths to have access to income that reduced vulnerability.
2.	Engaging youths in agriculture, especially training youths on the use of ox ploughs

1.	Cash/Food for asset – encouraged youths to work and enabled youths to have access to income that reduced vulnerability.
2.	Engaging youths in agriculture, especially training youths on the use of ox ploughs

Programming Gaps/Agriculture:
1.	Few youths targeted with vocational training opportunities.
2.	Few cattle and ox ploughs
3.	Limited economic empowerment opportunities for youths

Shocks/Flood:
1.	Major shocks include: conflict between farmers and cattle keepers in 2019 to 2020 – crops destroyed and displaced farmers.
2.	Floods – August to October every year.
3.	Economic shock – due to limited economic opportunities for youths and high level of unemployment among the youths.

Intervention Type/Livelihoods: The county agriculture development work closely with community to provide them with skills on best agriculture practices, and how to control pest and diseases. They liase with IPs like FAO, to support farmers with trainings and agricultural inputs. Hope agent for relief and development (HARD), Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development (ACTED) and JOHANNITER support the community of Jur River in various ways including food security and livilihood. Training  of small scale business and Village saving loan association.

Shocks/Flood: The county agriculture development has been doing a lot of awareness to the community to be resilience interms of producing their own seeds and not relying on external help and majority of people are already doing so. Communities are slowly moving out from waiting for assisstance to being independent. If not because of the freequent  flood,  Jur River used not to depend on humanitarian aids.

Shocks/Medical Condition: Climent change and disease. ( long dry spell and flood) affect agriculture seasons so much. Some adaptive seeds that are being brought from outside the country sometimes get affected by the climent.  The rain normally delays like now it is  the month of May and there is no rain yet, and shortly between September there will be too mcuh rain that may lead to floodings. These changes destroys most long term  crops like type two maize and  sorghum                                                                                                                                                              The high risk flood affected areas in Jur River are Marial Bai, Udici, some parts of Kangi and some bomas like Mbili in Kuajieno. These areas get affected yearly and causes migrations in the county. Natural disaster affects both men and women but obviously it has much effect on children and elderly people

Programming Gaps/Agriculture: During lean seasons, majority of the community depends on wild roots and vegetables. Those days they used to depend on world food program which has stopped already. With the two common natural disaster in Jur River, there is little realization of development however, the community are not giving up on trying to adapt to the circumstances.

Programming Gaps/Health: The situation remains the same because the government has no capacity to support health facilities with drugs and this calls for donors intervention.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: Approaches used were peace dialogue among the communities involved in the raiding and early preparation of farm land while waiting for rainy season.

There is a change in the County because in the past, people were not practicing kitchen gardens but now most of the households have the kitchen garden in their compounds. The community has open school farm fields in 4 out of 7 primary schools such as Choroi, Karukomunge, Riwoto, and ST Mary primary schools. The community members have taken their children to school both boys and girls yet in the past year's girls were not considered due to sensitization from education partners, now the community has known the importance of girl child education. The youths are now engaged in doing small business in the county not like before hencefored, there is much improvement in Kapoeta North in last 12 months compared to last years back.

Stresses/Conflict: The main shocks and stressors are Cattle raiding amongest the neighbours communities of Murle, Buya Tenent and Drought ( Long dryspell) which are not frequently practice. The county was affected during cattle raiding where members lost lives and resources (Cattles) which is main source of income in the county, while  youths, men and women became traumatized after losing their loved ones and cattles. The incident increased the number of widows in the county.

Intervention Type/Education: yes, there is a lot of improvement because the County has improved in terms of service delivery in the business sector. Many people have known the importance of business, education, and agriculture in the entire County and most households have sent their children to school both girls and boys than before where the boys were accepted only to be taken to school.

Stresses/Conflict: The economy in terms of dollar rates frequently raises up and down hence affecting business people when they need to restock their shops and later they sell at losses.  when the dollar rate raises up, reduces the supply of goods in the County.                                                                                                                                                                                                  Insecurity is stressful to businessmen who purchase their goods from Juba and end up being attacked along the way by robbers leading to loss of lives and properties. henceforth slows business in the County.                                                                                                                                                                                       Impassable roads during the rainy season delay business people's goods from reaching on time due to muddy and flowing rivers along the road keeping them overstaying in the bush. cattle raiding and drought which made most of the members migrate from the County in search of a peaceful place and green pasture for their animals.                                                 Increment of taxes by the county government leads to a rise in prices which affects the community.

Shocks/Flood: Taxes were reduced                                                                                                                                                                                         Being friendly to people in the trading center                                                                                                                                                     Wait until the rivers and the roads dry up                                                                                                                                           Purchase enough goods and services during the dry season

Programming Gaps/Coordination: There is a need for the partners to be quick in response to shocks like flooding, wildfire, and heavy winds. When information is passed to the partners, they tend to delay during intervention  and most of the Payams were affected by flooding too but there was no help at all.

Shocks/Drought: Cattle Raiding and Drought                                                                                                                                                                                                                                              During cattle raiding, many people lost their lives and properties causing trauma to youths who lost their colleagues during raiding and women lost their husbands and their relatives as well.

Intervention Type/Nutrition: Edward Lopoche is my name, am the County RRC Coordinator. Through RRC, the community gets sensitization to crop farming and other local production with the help of partners who support agriculture activities in the County and people get to learn the skills for farming. A good number of members in the community defend on cattle keeping and therefore his institution keeps encouraging the community to rare their animals as well as take nutritious food always by balancing the diets, as their institution monitors the improvement of the situation among the members.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: Peace dialogue among Toposa, Murle, Buya, and Tenent communities                                                                                                                                                            Preparing field farms and wait for rain

Intervention Type/Livelihoods: The peace dialogue because with peace the community can have barter trade with other communities that are involved in cattle raiding and also the community can produce enough food when the community members are living in harmony with other neighboring communities and these will improve the development of schools, health and big centers for selling and buying of local products that being produce by locals.

Intervention Type/Health services: The health facilities can be accessed by most of the members which was hard some years back to access. the community has brought their children to school willingly both boys and girls yet in the past boys were only allowed to go to school. the community members have practice hygiene and as you can see the center is clean. The County has improved in terms of business where most of the youth engaged themselves in business activities as well as women.

Intervention Type/Livelihoods: Yes, the situation in this County has improved and most of the household members have access to the market through the opening of feeders roads that connect bomas to the main center.
Shocks/Drought:
cattle raiding 
drought (dryspell)                                                                                                                                      
The shocks are not frequent but occurs occasionally                                                                     
 The County was affected most recently, Members lost lives, colleagues, and cattle to the raiders. Many young productive youths become traumatized after the incident.

Intervention Type/WASH: My Name is Rose Lomare and I am the chair lady for the women group in Kapoeta North. Through my office, women have access to improve health services, hygiene awareness, and promotion, the creation of VSLA/SILC groups, CWMC, distribution of Dignity kits, and awareness on the importance of CLTS with the help of partners. Women are sensitized on the importance of crop farming and rearing animals and most of the members are practicing with the knowledge of having a food diet always than eating the same meal. Women are running most of the business in the center through knowledge and skills acquired from partners' pieces of training.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: The approach used to address cattle raiding is peace dialogue among the communities involved in raiding and the approach used to address the drought (dry spell) is by preparing the farming land early and wait for the rainy season.

Intervention Type/Nutrition: the peace dialogue because when the community live in peace and harmony the business will boom up and there will be promotion of selling the local products to the market where women take charcoal to the center and sell.the women will able to have grass cutting in far places for their houses when the peace is there and also the community will harvest a lot of food from their peaceful cultivation in the community leading them to be independed people.

Intervention Type/Education: There is a change in the County because in the past people were not practicing kitchen gardens but now most of the households have the kitchen garden in their compounds. the community through education awareness has taken their children to school willingly both boys and girls than before when boys were the only ones that can be allowed to join the school. IPs' training on entrepreneurial skills led the community members aware of the importance of business and therefore many shops have been added in the past 12 months.

Shocks/Drought: The main shocks and stressors are the cattle raiding between neighboring communities and drought( Long dry spell) and they are not frequent. The county was affected when many people lost lives and cattle during raiding causing most of the youth to be traumatized. Many men and women lost their young ones during the cattle raid and some of the women lose their husbands which lead to the increased number of orphans and widows in the county.

Intervention Type/WASH: Saverio Pasquale and I am the County Executive Director. The County government coordinates with the implementing partners to address the community on the importance of agricultural activities, the opening of feeder roads, Hygiene promotion & awareness about the improvement of the livelihood. The partners also support the government in every activity to benefit the entire population. The County provides health education sessions to all the people and the County authority has joined the plan always with partners in doing an assessment first in any affected villages to acquire more information for decision making which will help in mitigating the risks.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: The approach used to address cattle raiding is peace dialogue among the communities involved. The approach used to address the drought (dry spell) is by preparing the farmland early and waiting for the rain while the community also defends on the GFD ratio.

Shocks/Drought: The main shocks and stressors are the cattle raiding between neighboring communities and drought(dry spell) which are not frequently experienced. The county was affected due to the loss of lives and resources, where resources such as cattle were the main livelihood activity in the county. Kapoeta North in general experience a long dry spell due to the delay of rain this year, they majorly focus on General Food Distribution provided by ADRA and cash for assets provided by CRS to mitigate the long dry spell.

Intervention Type/Agriculture: The approach used to address cattle raiding is peace dialogue among the communities involved in cattle raiding and the approach used to address the drought (dry spell) is by preparing the farming land early and wait for the rain.

The approach used to address cattle raiding is peace dialogue among the communities involved in cattle raiding and the approach used to address the drought (dry spell) is by preparing the farming land early and wait for the rain.

Intervention Type/Health services: There is a lot of improvement in terms of community resilience. The community has picked and coped with the strategies after receiving training from the partners on the awareness and importance of personal hygiene, and CLTS to avoid open defecations. and to cope with life through trauma healing. The community has improved in agriculture and most of the members have known the importance of crop farming and rearing of the animals as well.

Intervention Type/WASH: There is a lot of improvement in terms of community resilience. The community has picked and coped with the strategies after receiving training from the partners on the awareness and importance of personal hygiene, and CLTS to avoid open defecations. and to cope with life through trauma healing. The community has improved in agriculture and most of the members have known the importance of crop farming and rearing of the animals as well.

Programming Gaps/Infrastructure: Lack of transportation for the victims after the raids lead to the death of some victims.
Programming Gaps/Violence Prevention: There is a need to have laws and regulations to abide by all communities involved in the agreement and if any communities break those laws will be punished.

Shocks/Drought: I am Elia Iko, the chairperson of the youth in Kapoeta North. The youth in the County plays a big role in supporting the community to have food by doing a small business by bringing food items in the nearby communities, the youths assist their parents and their wives in farming, including the creation of awareness in the community on the importance of nutrition to community members so that they can practice balance diet always. The youths rear animals in the community and assist members during shocks like flooding or outbreak of fire by carrying people's properties to a safe place, the youth body has a plan in place to address disaster management that organize to mitigate the flooding by digging the dykes in affected Payams such as Paringa, Chumakori and Lomeyen respectively.

Stresses/Conflict: The main shocks and stressors are cattle raiding among the neighboring communities and drought (dry spell) and they are not frequent. The county is affected when many people lose life during cattle raiding and their head of cattle were taken causing most of the youth to have trauma after losing their colleagues and their cattle. Many men and women lose their young ones during the cattle raid and some of the women lose their husbands. The stressor is alcohol consumption among the members leading to Gender Base Violence.

The main shocks and stressors are cattle raiding among the neighboring communities and drought (dry spell) and they are not frequent. The county is affected when many people lose life during cattle raiding and their head of cattle were taken causing most of the youth to have trauma after losing their colleagues and their cattle. Many men and women lose their young ones during the cattle raid and some of the women lose their husbands. The stressor is alcohol consumption among the members leading to Gender Base Violence.

Intervention Type/Nutrition:
Intercommunal fight; People normally monitor the situation and prepare for their safety through alerts from state government who leak information to community members.
Peace partners have supported with dialogues with communities to peacefully coexist and also monitor intercommunal conflicts for communities in Pibor, Akobo and Bor who have interlocutors and give information or alerts if some is to happened like a planned attack.
Drought; Actors/partners have been trying to respond to change in climate by giving peope humanitarian food aid (GFD) and other give unconditional food to vulnerable population in the villages to reduce the adverse effects of drought and hunger.

Stresses/Conflict: There is no improvement owing to continuous intercommunal fightings. Communities organize themselves in numbers and attack neigboring communities kill people, destroy properties and take all valuation items which has kept Pibor under under emergency activities year in year out. For instance last year an attack happen were children where children taken, lifes lost, animals taken.

Programming Gaps/Violence Prevention:
There is a need to change mind set of communities to prepare for development. For example there is a need to educate people to leave peaceful and avoid intercommunal conflicts, disaster preparedness interms of flooding if all those are effected there will be a change in peoples livelihoods in Pibor County.
Humanitarians need to increase resilience projects so that communities can cope up with the emerging shocks and stressors

Shocks/Flood:
The main shocks and stressors in Pibor are; intercommunal conflicts, droughts, hunger, and flooding.
A
Conflicts which takes the form of organized intercommunal fights/attacks. This happens yearly and normally takes people un aware.
Drought the unpredictable rains is also major schock like people have planted thinking rains will start in April but till now it is still dry and the crops are going to die with the delays of rainfall.
Hunger has also hit the county. On yearly basis people tend to exp
Flooding is one of the shocks. It used to take 8 years to experience flooding but of recent that seem to have changed. The county was hit by flooding consecutively in 2017, 2019, 2020 and 2021 that explains some of the chanllenges households are facing now.

B
Conflict; people lost both life and properties.
Drought; has now worsened on the ability of the households to grow crops and vegetables which could supplement on whatever little the households have thus exacerbating the hunger situation in the Pibor.
Flooding; during flooding time people lost properties and livestock as there no many higher lands nearby. People were rendered useless as they couldnt do anything for their livelihoods but rather depended on support got from NGOs and or government to smaller extend.

Intervention Type/Health services:
The situation has somehow improved compared last 12 months because NGOs have supported communities in varried areas but mostly primary health health care, food security and other livelihood activities though the support is not enough because people continue to come to Pibor center from other communities outside Pibor town.
Last year Dinka communities from Bor attacked Gumuruk area of Pibor and the effect was feld allover Pibor so people dont have their livelihoods they used to have as everything was looted, destroyed and people killed.

Programming Gaps/WASH:
Inadequate of schools and teachers. Parents normally mobilize money to pay for teachers.
Children study under trees said the Payam Admin.
Pibor has no good health services. MSF used to support since and beyond 2008 to 2020 after they moved out of Pibor there have been no good health service providers. The county deserve to have hospital but so far there is no hospital in the county. JAM NGO now called For Africa is only implementing primary health care services and complicated case is reffered to Juba for further ttreatment/management. Akelo Payam doesnt have even PHCU

Payam Admin noted development artners should come and fill in the gaps especially for health and education. These gaps stresses the communities and thus affecting their resilience. 
Apparently there are no enough medicines in the facilities.
Government needs to construct the roads connecting Greator Pibor Administrative Area (GPAA). Saying the county locked. Everything come to Pibor through air and that has made commodities expensive in the local market. A case inpoint a 20 litre of diesel is closong to 70,000ssp more than tripple the price in Juba.

Programming Gaps/Life skills:
Humanitarian Assistance to communities is the most helpful approach because no one was there to give such a support to people suffering the flooding though there was some support from government like in Tolo island people were about to be engulfed by water and government sent boat to ferry people away from there.
A
The shocks and stressors have affected development because focus has to change to face the shocks than other planned activities that could be developmental to the county/communities.
B
People are seen resilient because every year the shocks happen but people continue to leave and face the shocks in any way though they are mostly been supported through.

Programming Gaps/Infrastructure:
Intercommunal fight; Government has tried to engage warring commuities in dialogue but was not very successful. Government also briefed local chiefs on peaceful coexistence and chiefs took the messages down to the communities the impact is yet to be seen.
Flooding; for flooding, communities have not prepared themselves to face to face any floding that might come and communities also dont know when flooding will occur that puts them in wrong position to withstand the effects. Last time people had to run to higher land like Lokurinyang inAkelo Payam.
NGOs supported with NFIs like plastic sheets, blankets, and LLITNs and also food aid given to community members.

Shocks/Flood:
The main shocks and stressors in Pibor are; intercommunal conflicts, hunger, and flooding.
A
Conflicts in Pibor tend to happen yearly and the attackers normally attack in June and December now its May communities are begining to get worried if neigboring communities would come and attack Pibor. 
Hunger in Pibor tend to affect people yearly.
Flooding  used not to be frequent but the recurring flooding of 2019, 2020 and 2021 affected communities adversely to the extend people were not able to do anything for living but rather depended on assistance from individuals and NGOs
B
Conflict; The intercommunal fights have led to loss of lifes and properties, displacements and abduction of children.
Hunger; the long spell of the dry season also worsened the hunger situation of households in Pibor because what people people have planted are drying thus widening the food insecurity gap.
Flooding made it diffult for communities to grow crops and vegetables that also explains continuos hunger situation in households.
C
The shocks and stressors affect both men and women equally for instance taking/abduction of children is very painful to both parents and also killing of community members or any one in the households affects all gender. Which is therefore the same with other shcks like the flooding and drought

Intervention Type/Nutrition:
Government evacuated people to higher lands during the pick of the flooding. Some community members in Vertet were evacuated to Pibor town for safety.
NFIs materials like (LLITNs, blankets, plastic sheets etc) and basic/emergency shelter given to all household affected.
Use of plastic sheets as boat to transport household properties and people.
Age set dialogues organised in collaboartion with Women Union, GRADO, VSF, Non Violence Peace Force, FCA, DT Global and Peace Canal.
Training on trauma and peacebuilding.
Government supported in settling IDPs in Pibor.
NGOs supported IDPs with cash, and food aid.
Programming Gaps/Education:
Lack of transport means for Women Union to go to far areas for dialogue activities.
Insecurity has affected service delivery, even one can be killed from the farm while farming.
Poor education standard. Teachers are poorly paid by the government and as result many run away from the profession.
Lack of hospiatal in Pibor. Health service delivery was initially run by MSF but since they left one implementing health right now is incapacitated.
Lack of boat for Women Union to use for its activities during rain season.

Women of Pibor are the most vulnerable and they need tools for farming.
Need to have a hospital in Pibor and
need to strengthen the education system.
Intervention Type/Livelihoods:
The situation has somehow improved compared last 12 months because NGOs have offered many capacity building trainings like tyloring, bread making and other area critical areas.
There used to fewer iron sheets seen on buildings but now there are many iron sheets in the community.
There is also an ongoing adult education for which is benefitial to women in Pibor who didnt have the chance for education.

Shocks/Flood:
The main shocks and stressors in Pibor are; intercommunal conflicts, age set fighting/conflicts, and flooding.
A
Conflicts in Pibor tend to happen yearly like 3 times a year. 
Age set fighting happens every year and mostly around May and June.
Flooding  used not to be frequent but the recurring flooding of 2019, 2020 and 2021 affected communities adversely to the extend people were not able to do anything for living and the effects are felt till today.
B
Conflict; The intercommunal fights have created IDP situation in the county, lack of food for the affected communities, loss of life and properties, children and women abducted during the conflicts.
Age set fights promotes misunderstanding and a culture of violence amongst youth in the community.
Flooding led to death of many livestock, farmlands destroyed, wash away properties of households, and people sometimes die as result of the conditions caused by flood. 
C
Children fighting and killing each other is so painful to mothers who know the pain of delivery and up bringing of children than men who dont feel such a pain like women do.
However flooding affects both men and women the same.
Intercommunal conflicts affects both both men and women the same.

Intervention Type/Peacebuilding:
NFIs (blankets, plastic sheets, LLITNs, etc) distributed to IDPs displaced as a result of flooding and conflicts.
Dialogue forums organized by partners to tackle the problem of age set fighting in the community and intercommunal conficts spearheaded by Non Violence Peace Force and others.
CRS supported with GFD activities to the affected communities.
Government settled IDPs who fled conflict from Lekuangole, Gumuruk and other areas in Pibor.

Intervention Type/Nutrition:
GFD approach was the most helpful support given by partners because with the food people were going to die of hunger.
The food given gave communities the resilience to withstand the shock.

Intervention Type/Peacebuilding:
There is an improvement because;
There are capacity-building activities to women in the areas of GBV, Peace, skilled training in tailoring etc.
Nowadays women have some level of voice in the community which used not to be the case.
There are at least commodities for people to buy in the local market though the prices are relatively higher.

Programming Gaps/Health:
Poor education service delivery to the people of Pibor like teachers are not been paid well who prefer to leave the profession as result.
Health service provision is not good enough with inadequate drugs.
High insecurity on the roads, leading to and from Pibor which affects movement of people.

Stresses/Conflict:
The main shocks and stressors in Pibor are; intercommunal conflicts, age set fighting/conflicts, and flooding.
A
Flooding occured in 2019, 2020 and 2021 but the effects are felt till now.
Intercommunal  conflicts and age set fights happen frequently more than 3 times a year.
B
IDP situation is created as a result of intercommunal conflicts.
Loss of life and properties destroyed during the conflicts/fights.
Flooding destroyed properties of people and caused displacement.
Age set fights promotes a culture of violence amongst the community. 
C
Women get affected more than the men because women cant run and leave their children during flooding and conflicts. Feed, and run with the children while get are either not there or enaged in confronting the fight.

Intervention Type/Protection:
Government solders escort communities to distribution centers which are far for communities who come from Vertet, Gumuruk and Lekuangole.
Training of women, youths and elders on peace building.
Women received dignity kits, a project implemented by Plan International, CIDO, Voice of Peace.
Nutrition activities for the PLWs (pregnant and lactating women) and children.
NGOs have distributed plastic sheets for erecting shelters for the IDPs and during flooding.
Plan International gave canoes given to communities during flooding.
GFD activities for the communities affected by CRS.

Intervention Type/Peacebuilding:
The situation has improved because;
Age set fights have reduced to every two or three months but it used to be more frequent.
Commodities are available in the market for people to buy except that they are expensive.
People used to be attacked and or killed when you go to the farm but that has reduced.
Intercommunal conflicts have reduced because of awareness activities supported by partners in Pibor.

Programming Gaps/Violence Prevention:
Giving out free things year in year out is training people to be lazy and don’t work.
Far places are not getting services provided by either government or NGOs.
Insecurities on the roads, intercommunal conflicts, age set fights affects service delivery to the needy communities.
Age set fighting affects schools because whenever such fights start schools close immediately because it that does spillover to the schools.
There is no hospital in Pibor. For Africa NGO is only implementing primary health care services in Pibor with challenges of lack of essential drugs.

Stresses/Conflict:
The main shocks and stressors in Pibor are; intercommunal conflicts, age set fights, rape and adultary cases, robbery on the roads leading to and from Pibor town, Early marriage, and flooding.
A
Intercommunnal conflicts in Pibor tend to happen 2 to 3 times yearly.
Age set fights happen more than 3 times a year.
displacements caused by massive flooding which effects are felt todate.
Road robberies, rape, adultary do happen frequently.
Early marriage is a common practice in Pibor.
Elders fear dialoguing with the youths involved in age set fights for fear of being killed.
Age set fights have led to seperation of people/family members because the youth just join any of the groups for such fights.
B
Conflict; The intercommunal and age set fights have led to loss of lifes and properties, displacements, cattles raided, creation of hunger condition and abduction of children.
road robberies; affects movement on the roads because of fear yet people need to move to look for their livelihood activities.
Flooding made it diffult for communities to grow crops and vegetables that also explains continuos hunger situation in households.
C
Women are the major victims of all the shocks like the rape which really traumatises women for the rest of their lives.
Women move into the forests to look for wild fruits for their families and get attacked in the forests.
Women lose their children to age set fights which is a painful thing to women.

Intervention Type/Nutrition:
Construction of dykes by the Youth Union to prevent flooding from spilling over to the whole community.
Plan International and OXFAM distributed sacks to built dykes.
CIDO and other agencies distributed plastic sheets for the construction of temporary shelters.
GFD provided by CRS to support communities with food.
UNCEF distributed temporary tents to erect shade for school children.
The peace-building activities efforts done by partners (Sheja salam, SALT, Non Violence Peace Force and UNMISS) have not yielded the intended results because the activities are implemented far away from the conflicting communities like those in the cattle camps and far villages are were the activities should be implemented not inside Pibor.

Intervention Type/Peacebuilding:
Aware communities on GBV and gender inequality in Pibor.
Monitor the work of the Chiefs in addressing conflicts and were they have challenges, the Youth Union comes in to strengthen the approaches of addressing conflicts.
Facilitate dialogue amongst age set conflicts.
Advocate for the rights of the youths from the NGOs interms job opportunities for the youths were there is a need to see youths occupying local positions.
Raise awareness against early marriage and forced marriage to avoid likelihood impacts on the youth.
Advocate aganst cattle raiding, intercommunal conflicts, child abduction which are frequently happening in Pibor.
Work hand in hand with the government to dialogue with youths in Pochalla though this activity is still in progress but the intentions are good for both communities of Pibor and Pochalla.

Programming Gaps/Violence Prevention:
Identify educated youth to teach in schools given the lack of teachers in the county because majority seem to desert the profession.
Seek for funds from NGOs in Pibor to implement youth led activities though currently the Union doesn’t have funds.
Conduct games and sports activities for peace and to keep youths busy not to be diverted by the age set fightings/conflict.

Programming Gaps/Nutrition:
Peace building projects need to target far away locations where the real issues of conflicts are.
Returnees don’t have ration cards because at the time of registration they were not there but the IP CRS needed to consider registering those communities who have not been registered to be registered to get food ration.
Communties are not getting information on GFD days because there is no phone network coverage in most of the areas in Pibor. That means the IP could get general raion cards so that people can get food any where were they are displaced.
Poor health service delivery inPibor. There are cases of people dieing owing to lack lack of drugs and mobile clinics.
Plan International is giving learning materials for schools but it would be good if another partner can take up incentives or salary for teachers especially the volunteer teachers.
There is no secondary school in Pibor
GBV activities are not reaching the grassroot properly. The people who badly need the GBV services are those dep in the villages. Hope Restoration is implementing GBV activities but the project is just 2 months and its coming to an end this month.

IPs need to engage all the stakeholder in the county to plan on the areas best suited for interventions based on the project type. The interventions are good but not been implemented in the right places/areas.
Services should go to far locations were GBV, conflicts, health, and education challenges are dire.
There is absolute need to form council of chiefs to best handle recurring cases in the community.

Stresses/Conflict:
Shocks/stressors include; Flooding, intercommunal violence, age set fighting, forced marriage, early marriage, rape, road ambushes and poor health service delivery.
A
Most of the shocks and stressors happen frequently like forced marriage, early marriage, rape, and road ambushes.
Intercommunal conflicts happen more than two or three times a year.
The flooding happened in 2019, 2020 and destroyed lots properties which effects are felt till today. 
B
Flooding destroyed properties and caused displacement of communities.
Forced marriage and early marriage victims have mostly decided not to come back to Pibor.
Abduction of children and women. For the women abducted felt they are mistreated from their own communities in Pibor and felt much better in those areas they taken.
Loss of life and properties during intercommunal conflicts and age set fighting.
destruction of social structure in the community during intercommunal fights.
Vulnerability increased as result of conflicts leaving many orphans.
Increase in the number of widows in the community.
Hunger in the community as result of lack of food since everythings are taken or destroyed during community violence.
Cattles taken by neighbors involved in raiding/conflicts made many household to be more poorer.
Rape affects women by way of getting STI/HIV and a permanent trauma
C
Women get affected differently like when men are killed are left as widows with all the burden of bringing up children etc.
Age set fight; when the youth come to the house and dont find the person they are looking for they end up beating women at home.
Women are the one taking care of the children so they suffer to do anything to get food for their children while men are doing nothing most times.
Rape affects women baddly interms of long term trauma, un wanted pregnancy and are suseptible to STI.

Intervention Type/Livelihoods:
Does all the activities for extesion support to farmer groups.
Responsible for day to day affairs of the organization (finance, logistics and program activities) incharge of everything in Pibor.
Attend coordination meetings to share progress and challenges facing the project.
Capacity building of farmer groups in best agculture practices.
Formed 30 farmer groups for field crops and vegetable, bee keeping, 6 fishing groups, 25 members in each group with 750 beneficiaries in total.
Train mother care groups to pass SBC messages targeting mothers/families with under 5 children.
Formed 250 beneficiaries for small ruminants (goats, rabits and paultry) to help communities diversify diet.
Groups for small ruminants are yet to receive training.
Framer groups are yet to receive their seeds and tools.
Established 3 demonstration plots of 2 fedans per fedan.

Programming Gaps/Health:
Non Violence Peace Force conducted peace dialogues among the youths with other counties.
Sheja Salam also conducted peace dialogues among the conflicting communities.
For disease nothing much seen from the health partners.
Provision of seeds to the communities by DAI, FAO, For Africa.
DAI trained different farmer groups on agronomic best practices.
Oxfam provided unconditional cash to targeted communties.
Programming Gaps/Nutrition:
Lack of labor saving equipment for farmers like oxploughs, soloar power.
For RASS project there is need to have one focal person to act as a bridge between farmers and DAI.
GFD activities have no alternatives for the beneficiaies to receive food especially where the head of the household dies the household members cant receive food. At least the partner needs to consider registration yearly to cater for such eventualities in the household.

Intervention Type/Livelihoods:
Things have improved generally because;
There is some relative peace in the county.
Women nowadays move to collect firewood in the forest bad no much is heard about any case of assault, beating, rape, abduction etc.
Many communities have some sizeable farmland because people realized dependance on humanitarian is not sustainable and the IPs are building the capacity of the communities to be resilient.

Shocks/Medical Condition:
Shocks/stressors include; Flooding, intercommunal violence, age set fighting, child abduction, hunger and sicknesses.
A
Intercommunal conflicts; do happen 2 to 3 times a year.
Age set fights; happens like 5 times a year
Diseases; are at pick during rain season especially malaria becomes most common sickness and that is worsened by the lack of a hospital in the county.
Hunger; happens throughout the year.
B
Intercommunal conflicts; loss of lives and properties, cattles raided, destruction of social services and structures.
Age set fights; creates disunity among the youths and fear in the community, whenever age set fights start NGO activities are all halted.
C
The named shocks and stressors mostly affect both men and women especially intercommunal conflicts and age set fights.
Age set fights affects mostly men/youth.
Diseases affects both men and women the same.

Intervention Type/Peacebuilding: 1. The community reports concerns in the area to the Chief and the Chief discusses them with the members and assessing the nature of the concern and recommend the appropriate action at community level 2. Issues that are complex such as that of killing are refered to the government authority to address it according to the law. For instance the killer of the wife was arrested and sentenced to jail.

Vulnerable Population/Women: Over the last 12 months, the shock and stressors that a noticeable include; killings, a group of bad youth calling themselves 'niggas' surfaced and threatening people within the community, and at family level, there were cases of GBV. For instance, one husband knived his wife 10 times and other reports said 14 times instead leading to the death of the wife. This was later taken up by the government and the killer was arrested and the law followed accordingly.                                                a). This happens occassionally as far as the frequency is concerned.                                                                                                                                                                                          b). The effects especially of the bad behaviours like killing of wife are severe at househodl level and to the community. First, it means the family will not be the same again as they lose a member of the family. Secondly, there will be no body to provide the basic things like foods, clothes etc for the children if any. Thirdly, if any children, they are likely to get unattended and become part of the bad guys (''niggas'') in the course of the time. It means the shocks and stressors will increase instead of reducing.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      c). In our community, most of the shocks seems to be affected the women more than the men as the women as percieved as weak and one example is the killing of the wife by the husband using knife.

Vulnerable Populations/Youth:
From the above, approaches, the most helpful ones are providing skills training to the youth so that they get skills and knowledge to do something meaningful as source of living. The approach taken by the government is also another good one because without this intervention, the citizens will have limited option and die of hunger.
a.Training the youth with various skills enables them to participate in development of the county, the state and the whole of South Sudan. Thus, builders would be taking up contracts to earn money and the same with those will have completed carpentry, painting etc.
b.Issues of suicide reduce the population hence less labour force (youth) that could work and get food for themselves and their relatives. This leaves them weak and won’t resist any shock and stressors in the community. The increase in the prices affects the profits of those who do business as source of living and leaving them vulnerable and less resilient
Stresses/Drought: "The main shocks and stressors that affected the community in the this county in the last 12 months include; Presence of ‘’nigga’’ who threaten the free movement of the people especially in the urban areas as they rob and beat people, increase in prices and drought that has affected those and suicide of both youth and elderly. The presence of drinks also has spoiled the youth.

Stresses/Conflict:
This respondent repeated that the prices keep on increasing and going higher and higher. For instance, that a bar of soap is now at 1,400 SSP making it less affordable by those who do not have this money.
Additionally, the displaced person given the war in Sudan is of great concern especially to the government. This means more people are coming yet there are not ready things for welcoming them. So far, WFP had stopped distribution of food and this makes it difficult as to how they people (both stayees and returnees) to survive. According to him, he foresees more suffering and difficulties ahead which will affect the people capacity to being resilient.
Intervention Type/Agriculture: He is called William Danie and works as the County Coordinator for the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission of Wau. His work is to link the RRC with the chiefs, create awareness various issues, receive the people who are coming to the county from other counties(displaced) and linking with UNHCR for assistance. a). according to him, he is also involved in helping the citizens rturn to their places as well as helo to get foo through the organization. Thus, he requests for seed to be distributed to the settlers of particular location so that they can produce and address the shock of food insecurity and subsequent hunger. Through the NGOs, the people are also given inputs such as hoes, pangas, slashers etc to help them cultivate

Intervention Type/Livelihoods: The Key informant also report that for the behavior of ‘’nigga’’ in the community, they advocate for awareness among the youth to change their behaviour. Additionally, the present the issue of the youth to the NGOs in order to train them on skills that can make them earn decent living (carpentry, building, tailoring blacksmithing among others were mentioned). The existing schools are Don Bosco Skills training centre and some of NGOs include NRC that could support this program.

Stresses/Conflict: The effect of these shocks also vary. For instance, presence of the ‘Niggas’ threaten the movement of people and especially children to school as they may be exposed to rape and others forms of abuse. The high prices, affect the purchasing power of those who can access money while those without are likely to go without food. Accordingly, some of the people are just having a meal per day while others don’t for many days because they can’t afford. The suicide certainly brings trauma and more stress to the family which lost a member in addition to reducing the population and labour force incase where the young people are the ones committing suicide. There are also many funerals as a result of the suicide cases shifting the focus of the community from addressing other issues that face its members.

Perception of Stresses/Worsened:
The approaches that were most helpful are, peace, involving the NGOs for service delivery, reporting complex issues to the government and use of the community structures to address most community concerns.
a. Some of the approaches like dialogues affected development positively in a way that when the animal left, the farmers were above to continue with their activities until they harvested their crops. Unfortunately, this did not work for long when the animals/cattle returned again and have destroyed most of the farms leaving the owners(farmers) vulnerable of what and where find something to eat individually and at household level.  Part of Baggari Payam was affected by the cattle.
b. Destruction of crops as the main livelihood for the farmers surely leaves them empty and helpless. Therefore, the capacity of the community to be resilient has been greatly compromised.
Programming Gaps/M&E: To her, it appears that there is little collaboration between the IPs and the national organizations as some national organization have not entered into partnership. Additionally, there is the issue of the qualified national staff working with the national organizations leaving to work with international organizations. While this is ok, it reduces the capacity of the national organizations as they are left with no qualified staff. The issue of location and partnership seems to be more of a talk than being put in practice. The money given for service delivery should have proper monitoring system at the community level and the projects that are meant to benefit the women should not be diverted. Recruitment of staff to positions should be localized so that the youth who are graduates and have the relevant skills and knowledge can also access the job and improve their lives. Eventually, this will contribute positively to increasing the capacity of the local youth to withstand the shocks and stressors in the community of Wau and beyond. The issue of peacebuilding should be taken seriously because without peace, realizing development and becoming resilient as a community will be hard to reach. Finally, she thanked to Integrity Global for coming to carry out this exercise which gave the opportunity to express the concerns relating to the situation in Wau County.
Vulnerable Populations/Children: drop out of school children due to lack of school fees, displaced of people from their places of residence including the situation in Sudan, heavy drinking and consumption/abuse of drugs by the youth, change of names of places by people who do not belong to the area making conflict, land grabbing and poor and bad roads among others.

Shocks/Medical Condition: The frequency of all these shocks and stressors vary however, GBV happens very often. The issue of changing names of villages/places by displaced persons has been of recent but is increasing these days. Land grabbing also happens case by case. Diseases/sicknesses like malaria, flue and cough especially among children are very frequent in the community/Wau county.
Intervention Type/Education: Linda is the CEO of WOTAP (Women Training and Promotion) and this organization does gender equality, supports women by raising their level to participate in development. The organization works in the three counties of WBGS, but could also extend its services regionally in issues related to election. The work is mostly in the community where 80% of the people supported are women while in some projects they focus 100% on the women. Other key areas that they work on include education, awareness on HIV, hepatitis and GBV, women rights and advocacy on issues affecting the women right.

Programming Gaps/Education:
"Comparatively, the situation has improved over the last 12 months. This is because there are services like schools, health facilities and centres that are built for community use (women and children friendly spaces). There are also training facilities, markets and CDMRR who are trained to respond to issues in the community. The people also can move to burn charcoal to sell as one of the livelihoods.
However, there are still many challenges in education, health because they are few and inefficient. Hence, there is need for construction of more schools, health centres so that those who can’t access the services get them."

The critical gaps include; conflict of interest in service delivery, segregation and less cash distributed which did not cover all the school going kids and it leaves many to drop out of school, few medicines in the health facilities, and water is still limited to certain places while others do not have.

Stresses/Conflict: increase in prices/inflation, corruption with example of some people hoarding medicines which are meant for the public especially in the government facilities leading to increase in sicknesses, the politics of transferring the county capital from Wau Municipality to Baggari, Gender based violence

All the issues happening like land grabbing, change of names, corruption etc. breed conflict and instability in the community and threatening the potential to being resilient to the shocks and stressors. Additionally, the presence of the cattle on farmlands affects in the sense that no production will be realized when the crops are eaten by the cattle exposing the farmers to hunger, malnutrition and rampant deaths to due poor feeding as the people become susceptible to diseases.
c. Most of the shocks and stressors affect women but less for men instead.

Pereption of Stresses/Worsened:
"The introduction of short-term variety is good because they tend to mature early and may not be subjected to the drought. Unfortunately, the approach of having meetings and dialogue between the cattle owners and the farmers is not working because the cattle owners refuse to take their cattle away. As said, instead they turn to intimidate the farm owners by guns.
a. The approaches affect the development differently. In the case of short-term variety of seeds that were distributed by organizations like FAO, it means the farmers will be able to harvest their crops in the shortest time and this tend to act as food security as they have food to eat at household level, but also to sell the surplus to meet their other household needs like education of children, purchase of salt, soap, sugar etc. In short, the farmers can realize income when they harvest and sell more.
b. As for the cattle and drought, they affect the resilience of the communities negatively because they weaken the potential of farmers to withstand the shocks and stressors."

Intervention Type/Nutrition: For the case of animals/cattle eating farmer crops, the cases are usually reported to the government authorities who take it up and inform the cattle owners to move out from the places where there are crops. Similarly, organizations have also organized for some meetings and dialogues between the cattle owners and the farmers to resolve the conflict peacefully. Unfortunately, the cattle keepers are often adamant and hardly move out. Instead, they threat the farmers with guns. For the case of drought or lack of rain, the agriculture department together with it partner NGOs advocate for planting of short-term variety of seed that mature well in term. Some of the organizations like FAO do purchase the seeds for distribution.
Programming Gaps/WASH:
"To some extend there are no many gaps in the field of agriculture in the communities of Wau county because a number of partners are responding to the needs of the communities as far as seeds, trainings and supervision are concerned. However, some of the gaps that we could think of including absence of water harvesting system. Although this looks advance, it is good because it could solve the problem of drought where farmers could produce during dry season by using the harvested water to irrigate their crops.
Additionally, there are no solar systems that could help pump water to farmers’ gardens during the dry season."

Shocks/Drought:
here is presence of wildlife that sometimes destroy the crops of farmers. Additionally, there are cattle that trespass farms and eat crops of the farmers. There is no rain for a couple of months now.
a. The wildlife largely come when the crops ae near harvest hence not very frequent. The cattle are seasonal as they are driven in the nearby communities by the owners. It is said that some of them belong to some government officials. The absence of rain is also season and does not happen frequently.
b. The wildlife and the cattle destroy the crops and the effect in the county is that there is reduced food as farmers harvest less. The lack of rainfall has made some crops to dry up and the further effects is that there will be food insecurity and less food will be supplied to the urban center from the rural areas where farming taking place. Again, with the lack of rain, the farmers will not be able to plant the seeds which were distributed to them and the more the seeds stay, they are likely to get expired.
c. These shock and stressors affected both men and women in an equal manner because where there is lack of food at household level and in the market all of them suffer.

Programming Gaps/Agriculture:
"Firstly, Joseph appreciated Integrity Global for coming for this survey. Some of the things that he mentioned include the challenge of bush clearing and cutting of trees in order to leave the land good for cultivation. 
As it is, there are no tractor that could fell the trees. If these could be provided, the farmers would be able to cultivate large peace of land and produce more food. 
There are also issues of pests and birds that destroy the crops. 
It is also, NGOs do not cover the whole of Wau County in terms of agriculture hence, is good if the agricultural support and services are extended across the county to increase the level of productivity thereby addressing the shocks and stressors in the county. "
